misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the computer inherently understands that the valid range for a grade is 0-100 and that the logic only needs to cover this range, assuming values outside this range will not occur or will be handled automatically.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student's mental model assumes the computer has semantic awareness of the problem context. In reality, the Java virtual machine only evaluates the specific boolean expressions provided, meaning any value >= 90 (even 1000) results in "A", and any value not caught by previous conditions (even -5) results in "F".

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that a "numeric grade" is always a whole number, and thus the int type and nextInt() method are always appropriate for this task.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to realize that nextInt() is restricted to integer syntax and the int type cannot represent decimal values. The notional machine will throw a runtime exception if the user input contains a decimal point, even though decimals are "numeric".
